dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, huge news breaking out of the tech world, especially for anyone, uh, using social media. Kevin Mayer, the CEO of TikTok, he's, like, quit the company.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: TikTok CEO Kevin Mayer has quit the company just months after taking charge, as the Chinese-owned video-sharing app faces a possible ban following an executive order by Trump earlier this month that accused the platform of sharing U.S. user data with Chinese authorities, the Financial Times reported, citing an internal letter.

dialogue_turns.text: Right, the whole "possible ban" thing. Like, Trump's executive order saying TikTok's sharing U.S. user data with Chinese authorities, which, um, ByteDance denies, obviously.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He reportedly told employees Thursday that he was out. And the article says he, uh, didn't anticipate *this* level of tension between China and the US when he took the job in June.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He reportedly told employees Thursday that he was out. And the article says he, uh, didn't anticipate this level of tension between China and the U S when he took the job in June.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mayer reportedly informed employees at TikTok and its parent ByteDance of his decision to leave the company on Thursday. The report added that while taking over in June, Mayer had not anticipated the extent to which TikTok would become involved in tensions between China and the US.

dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Okay, good to know. But, like, Mayer, he's a big name. He helped launch Disney+, a massive success. And then he leaves Disney to join TikTok, only to leave TikTok...

dialogue_turns.text: Well, the report says he was actually passed over for the top CEO role at Disney, uh, which is why he, you know, looked elsewhere. He was, like, the internal favorite for a while.

On Monday, TikTok sued the Trump administration challenging the presidents executive order...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They are. They're challenging the executive order, saying it violates due process protections of the Fifth Amendment. They're fighting back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They are. They're challenging the executive order, saying it violates due process protections of the Fifth Amendment. They're fighting back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Monday, TikTok sued the Trump administration challenging the presidents executive order, stating that, By banning TikTok with no notice or opportunity to be heard (whether before or after the fact), the executive order violates the due process protections of the Fifth Amendment.

dialogue_turns.text: I saw that. And Mayer's internal letter, it, um, sounded pretty heavy. He said, "as the political environment has sharply changed, I have done significant reflection..."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I saw that. And Mayer's internal letter, it, um, sounded pretty heavy. He said, as the political environment has sharply changed, I have done significant reflection...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the Financial Times report, Mayer told employees in a letter, In recent weeks, as the political environment has sharply changed, I have done significant reflection on what the corporate structural changes will require, and what it means for the global role I signed up for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, "heavy heart" was definitely in there. And let's not forget Peter Navarro, the White House trade advisor, actually called Mayer an "American puppet" for working at the company.
